title: Riverside officials hope Chapel Drive bridge replacement is delayed until summer
text:
Larger font size Posted: Monday, October 19, 2015 11:45 pm 
NORTH SEWICKLEY TWP. -- A proposed bridge replacement project along Chapel Drive in March could mean Riverside students would be on a school bus up to 45 minutes more a day, district Superintendent David Anney said Monday. 
He's hoping PennDOT will delay the work until the school year is over. 
The replacement of the small bridge, which crosses an unnamed stream near Collins Road, would result in “delays that are pretty significant,” Anney said after Monday's school board meeting. The delays could be 40 to 45 minutes (round trip) per day, he said. 
During construction, there will be a detour that uses Harpers Ferry Road and Route 65 (Mercer Road). The length of the detour is listed as 6.6 miles, according to Plenary Walsh Keystone Partners. 
“We (the district) prefer the project starts in the summer,” Anney said. 
The project is scheduled to begin as soon as March 2016, Daniel Galvin, public information officer for Plenary Walsh Keystone Partners, said during a North Sewickley Township Supervisors meeting on Oct. 13. Replacement, through the Pennsylvania Rapid Bridges Replacement Project, would take four to five weeks to complete, Galvin told supervisors. 
Anney said he was in touch with Galvin on Wednesday and Galvin said he would contact PennDOT to possibly delay the project. 
The bridge is presently down to one traffic lane, and it was placed on a PennDOT list of bridges that need immediate replacement, Galvin said. After an inspection, though, it was determined that the bridge is safe to travel across, just that part of the facade had given away, Galvin said during the supervisors’ meeting. 
In other news, Anney said after the school board meeting that a flashing school speed limit sign along Country Club Drive near Riverside Memorial Stadium has been operational since Friday. 
The first steps for installing the lights began with a traffic study in early 2014 by North Sewickley Township Police Chief Jeff Becze. The cost of the lights totaled $24,229, and the work was performed by Traffic Systems and Services. The Riverside School District and the township shared equally in the cost.
